I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed senior 
unsecured loan of up to $80,000,000, comprising (i) an A loan of up to $30,000,000 (or its rupiah 
equivalent); and (ii) a B loan of up to $50,000,000 (in the event that the A loan or part of it is 
denominated in US dollars) to PT Indosurya Inti Finance (Indosurya) for the Small and Medium-
Sized Enterprise Financing Project in Indonesia. 
 
2.  The proposed loan to Indosurya will support the onlending and expansion of its small and 
medium-sized enterprise (SME) loan portfolio. Funding from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
will provide support for critically needed financial products and services to this underserved 
segment in Indonesia with targeted support for women SME clients and borrowers in less-
penetrated geographical markets, primarily outside Greater Jakarta. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
3.  Indonesia’s gross domestic product (GDP) has grown by an average of 5.5% annually 
since 2010, most recently expanding at 5.1% in 2017 and 5.2% in 2018. The economy is projected 
to grow at 5.2% in 2019 and 5.3% in 2020.1 In 2018, increased volatility in emerging markets 
impacted Indonesia, with the rupiah depreciating sharply against the US dollar. Bank Indonesia’s 
response of tightening monetary policy is credited with restoring stability and moderating inflation 
expectations from 3.8% in 2017 to 3.4% in 2018 and 3.5% in 2019.2 Despite these challenges, 
Indonesia’s investment-grade credit ratings were reaffirmed or even improved; Moody’s Investor’s 
Service upgraded its rating to Baa2 in 2018.3. As Indonesia’s economic growth and credit ratings 
strengthen, new ways to accelerate sustainable and inclusive economic growth are needed to 
meet ambitious economic and social targets, and to address household income inequality.4 
 
4.  Finance sector. Although a large economy, Indonesia’s finance sector is small and 
underdeveloped relative to its regional peers.5 Total financial system assets amounted to about 
72% of GDP in 2017. Banks dominate the sector with 74% of assets; securities companies 
account for 10% of assets; and the mutual funds industry, insurance companies, pension funds, 
and  multifinance  companies  (MFCs)  make  up  the  rest. 6  The  banking  system  is  highly 
concentrated with the top 20 banks accounting for about 80% of total assets. The four largest

banks account for almost 50%.7 The system is well capitalized, with a capital adequacy ratio of 
over 23% in 2018. It has adequate asset quality with a nonperforming loan (NPL) ratio of 3%;8 
and is profitable, with a return on average assets of 2% and a return on average equity of 20%. 
The Financial Services Authority of Indonesia (OJK) was established as an integrated regulator 
in 2011 and has overseen the entire finance sector since 2012, including Basel III implementation. 
In 2016, the Bank for International Settlements rated Indonesia largely compliant with the Basel 
III framework.9 
 
5.  Small and medium-sized enterprise sector. Most enterprises in Indonesia are small, 
usually  employing  fewer  than  20  people.  However,  their  contribution  to  employment  is 
significant—about 76%. It is estimated that there are more than 59 million enterprises, of which 
just over 1% are considered SMEs10 and about 98% are considered microenterprises.11 Women 
own almost 50% of SMEs in Indonesia.12 SMEs contribute about 22% to GDP, or 57% if 
microenterprises are included. The government prioritizes development of the sector. It has 
devised a legal framework13 involved several ministries in SME policy, (notably the Ministry of 
Cooperatives and SMEs); and has established a significant number of government programs 
supporting SMEs.14 
 
6.  Access to  finance.  The  proportion  of  the  adult  population  having  a  bank  account 
increased from 36% in 2014 to about 49% in 2017—the highest growth rate in the region.15 
However, access to credit remains very limited. Based on the 2017 Global Findex Data, only 18% 
of men and 17% of women in Indonesia borrowed from a financial institution, while 40% of men 
and 32% of women borrowed from family or friends and only 6% of borrowers reported that the 
money was used to start, operate, and/or expand a farm or business (footnote 15). The geography 
of the country also presents an additional barrier to credit access. In 2016, 69% of all formal loans 
were extended to borrowers in Java.16 
 
7.  Lending to SMEs has not been an area of primary focus for the banking sector. Some 
rural banks have catered to SMEs, although these banks tend to be smaller and their operations 
restricted by regulation to a designated territory. Only 12% of SMEs in the country have access 
to formal credit (footnote 11), underscoring the limited depth of financial inclusion. Women, in

particular, experience constraints in accessing funding for their businesses, including difficulties 
in meeting loan eligibility criteria because of lack of property ownership and, in some cases, limited 
business  experience.17 Furthermore,  few  financial  institutions  offer  products  and  services 
customized to address these constraints.18 Given that about 18% of banks’ loan portfolios are 
directed at SMEs, and most are for working capital purposes in the wholesale and retail sectors 
(53%), there is significant potential for growth. A World Bank study estimated the SME financing 
gap at more than $165 billion.19 
 
8.  Multifinance companies. Nonbank financial institutions, especially MFCs, have been the 
primary financial institutions catering to SMEs. MFCs are licensed, non-deposit-taking financial 
institutions  permitted  to  offer  financial  services  in  leasing,  consumer  financing,  credit  card 
financing, and factoring. In 2019, about 185 MFCs operated in Indonesia, the largest of which are 
associated  with  larger  banks  or  auto  manufacturers.  MFCs  mostly  target  retail  borrowers, 
financing vehicle purchases (70%), followed by wholesale leasing (27%) and factoring (3%) 
(footnote 19). MFCs are regulated by the OJK under a framework that encourages portfolio 
diversification, extending their range of permissible activities to include direct investment and 
working capital financing.20 
 
9.  Rationale.  To support SMEs’  access to  finance,  ADB’s  nonsovereign  operations  is 
pursuing financial institutions in Indonesia that have a successful track record in servicing this 
segment. Most recently, ADB has been supporting microfinance institutions directly and through 
the Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee Program.21 The proposed transaction would 
be the first nonsovereign operations project to partner with an MFC in Indonesia to fund SMEs. 
ADB selected Indosurya because of its focused strategy of funding SMEs through targeted 
outreach. Established in 2011, Indosurya now spans 70 branches along with various alliances 
with local agents and fintech partners. Indosurya received a national rating of A– by Fitch Ratings 
in  May  2018  as  a  result  of  its  satisfactory  asset  quality,  strong  profitability,  and  robust 
capitalization.22 
 
10.  The  design  of  the  proposed  transaction  builds  on  lessons  from  previous  ADB 
nonsovereign operations supporting SME financing in other countries. It incorporates realistic 
development targets and indicators; for the women SME targets, it includes a gender action plan 
(GAP) to enhance business sustainability. It also provides the option of local currency financing 
to avoid currency induced credit risk of ADB’s borrowers and their SME clients. Finally, a proposed 
technical assistance (TA), which will be approved separately, will also enhance Indosurya’s asset-
liability management, ensuring a more robust financing strategy.

B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
11.  Indosurya is a private, family-owned MFC based in Jakarta, specializing in collateral-
based SME financing through four main products: investment financing, working capital financing, 
multipurpose financing, and Sharia-compliant financing. In addition to its large branch network, in 
2017 Indosurya partnered with several peer-to-peer (P2P) platforms to increase the share of 
smaller loans. Indosurya had 991 staff members in April 2019.23 
12.  Indosurya manages a loan portfolio of about Rp3.6 trillion which represent about 1% of 
the estimated MFC market. The portfolio grew at a compound annual rate of 21% from 2014 to 
2018, and the company forecasts continued robust portfolio growth of 18% annually from 2019 to 
2023 by focusing on the untapped SME market. Indosurya also tries to lower its cost of funds to 
better compete with commercial banks for repeat business clients on their second loan cycles. 
Indosurya  is  streamlining  its  processing  to  lower  operational  costs  by  making  information 
technology  investments  to  (i)  develop  an  online  platform  to  support  end-to-end  customer 
application appraisal to disbursement and collections processing, (ii) enhance its existing core 
system to improve underwriting processes, and (iii) strengthen its liquidity and longer-term funding 
management. 
 
C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
 
13.  Ownership. Indosurya is part of a group of companies owned by the Surya family.24 The 
founder of Indosurya, Surya Effendy is the chair of its board of commissioners (BOC). The 
founder’s son, Henry Surya is the chief executive officer and chair of the board of directors (BOD). 
Integrity due diligence was conducted and identified no significant or potentially significant 
integrity risks.25 All of the ultimate beneficial owners have been identified and they do not appear 
to be subjects of any unresolved or substantiated adverse media or other information. Two 
members of the BOC are politically exposed persons, having served as directors in state-owned 
entities; however, neither is the subject of any adverse news. ADB’s review of the entity does not 
give ADB cause to believe that it is being used for money laundering or the financing of terrorism. 
Tax integrity due diligence was not required.26 
 
14.  Management. In addition to Henry Surya as chief executive officer, the key management 
team comprises non-family members, each with more than 10 years of experience in banking and 
MFC operations. They include Mulyadi Tjung, managing director; Junus Octora, chief financial 
officer; and Henli Salim, chief operating officer. 
 
15.  Governance structure. Indosurya’s governance structure is based on the regulatory 
framework established by the OJK.27 It functions in a two-tier board structure comprising the BOC, 
which  is  composed  of  three  commissioners,  including  the  chair,  Surya  Effendy,  and  two 
independent commissioners; and the BOD, which is composed of five directors, including the

16.  Risk management. These activities are centralized at the head office and managed in 
accordance with the risk management framework of the International Finance Corporation (IFC).29 
Policies  are  conservative,  with  a  clear  segregation  of  functions  in  the  operations,  credit 
underwriting and approval, and collateral appraisal to avoid conflict of interest between business 
origination and credit quality. There is a centralized credit assessment with mandatory client visits 
and collateral confirmation. Credit assessment also uses client cash-flow-based appraisal for 
credit scoring. All credit applications are submitted to the Credit Committee for approval.30 All 
applicants are cross-checked with the Financial Information Services System. 
 
D.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
17.  ADB will provide a senior unsecured loan to Indosurya of up to $30 million (or its rupiah, 
equivalent) of up to 5 years. In the event that the A loan or part of it is denominated in US dollars, 
ADB expects to syndicate a B loan of up to $50 million by mobilizing impact investors and other 
eligible B loan participants, subject to market conditions. ADB also expects to provide a TA to 
support and enhance Indosurya’s asset and liability management framework.31 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  Use of proceeds. Indosurya will use the total proceeds of ADB’s facility to finance SMEs 
in Indonesia with at least 25% of ADB’s A loan  used to fund women SME clients32 and at least 
25% of ADB’s funds would support SMEs in less-penetrated geographical markets, primarily 
outside Greater Jakarta.33  The B loan, dependent on the A loan, or part of it, being denominated 
in US dollars, would be targeted at up to $50 million. 
 
19.  Reporting arrangements. ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department will carry out 
project monitoring. Indosurya will prepare and submit to ADB financial and monitoring reports at 
predetermined  regular  intervals  and  as  requested,  including  (i)  annual  audited  financial 
statements; (ii) quarterly unaudited financial statements; (iii) quarterly compliance certificates for 
loan covenants; (iv) semiannual reporting on the loan portfolio; and (v) annual reporting on

C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
20.  Support small and medium-sized enterprises’ growth. ADB’s funding will support the 
growth of Indosurya’s SME loan portfolio, including its women SME financing portfolio. Some of 
the funding will also target geographic areas where access to finance is more limited, such as 
outside Greater Jakarta. Gender support initiatives will be implemented through the GAP. 
 
21.  Provide longer tenor debt. Indosurya has relied on local commercial banks for funding, 
mostly at shorter tenors, and capital market issuances of medium-term notes. To finance its longer 
tenor SME portfolio, Indosurya has sought matching financing, which is challenging for smaller 
MFCs in Indonesia. In addition to longer-term financing, ADB’s TA will help Indosurya strengthen 
its liquidity and longer-term funding management. 
 
22.  Catalyze private sector financing. If ADB’s A loan, or part of it, is denominated in US 
dollars, the B loan of up to $50 million will catalyze private sector capital and diversify Indosurya’s 
lender base. 
 
D.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
23.  Impact. The project will support financial inclusion through expanded access to finance 
by SME clients in Indonesia, especially focusing on women borrowers and borrowers in areas 
outside Greater Jakarta. The project is aligned with the government’s National Medium-Term 
Development Plan, 2015–2019, which seeks to promote financial inclusion.34 
 
24.  Outcome. The project’s outcome will improve sustainable SME lending activities. 
 
25.  Outputs. The outputs are increased lending capacity of Indosurya, in particular for women 
SMEs, and improved gender equity of Indosurya. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
26.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030,35 especially its operational priorities of (i) addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing inequalities by facilitating quality job creation through SMEs, and (ii) accelerating 
progress in gender equality by narrowing the gender gap through economic empowerment 
through better access to finance for women SMEs. The project is also consistent with ADB’s 
country partnership strategy for Indonesia, 2016–2019, which aims to support Indonesia by 
fostering higher and more inclusive growth, including by expanding access to financing to SMEs

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
27.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009).39 
28.  This transaction is classified as category FI for impacts on the environment and FI treated 
as C for involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. ADB conducted due diligence to assess 
the potential environmental and social impacts and risks associated with Indosurya's existing and 
future  portfolio,  and  its  capacity  to  implement  an  appropriate  environmental  and  social 
management system (ESMS). The multipurpose loans are only used for consumer or personal 
use (e.g., vehicle loans) are considered to have no environmental or social impacts. Most of the 
loan portfolio consists of investment loans and working capital loans. These are used for various 
business  sectors  including  trading,  hotel,  and  restaurant;  business  services;  construction; 
industrial; and freight, warehousing, and communications. Since the project involves the financing 
of SMEs with ADB proceeds, it will have very limited direct climate change impact. Sample 
subprojects in the hotel, construction, and industry sectors were visited as part of the due 
diligence. The subloans for these subcompanies were provided at a time when Indosurya had no 
formal environmental and social management procedures. The subcompanies comply with the 
regulatory environmental requirements in Indonesia. Indosurya will screen its future subprojects 
for  all  potential  environmental,  health  and  safety,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous 
peoples impacts and risks; and will require subborrowers to implement mitigation measures or 
prepare corrective action plans, as appropriate. 
 
29.  Indosurya  is  finalizing  its  ESMS,  which  it  initiated  when  the  German  Investment 
Corporation  (DEG)  provided  its  loan  to  Indosurya  in  2017.  ESMS  implementation  is  the 
responsibility of Indosurya’s Risk Management and Information System Department and the 
director of risk and information technology is concurrently assigned as the ESMS officer. As part 
of its organizational strengthening, Indosurya has committed to hire additional ESMS staff and 
engage a senior environmental and social consultant with the requisite background as it expands 
its business and geographic coverage. DEG, through its ESMS consultant, provided training on 
the ESMS to Indosurya to strengthen the capacity of relevant staff to undertake environmental 
and social safeguards screening, categorization, and monitoring. Before disbursement of ADB’s 
financing, the company will enhance the draft ESMS to harmonize the ESMS requirements of 
DEG and IFC with those of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.40 The ESMS will ensure that 
Indosurya will not use ADB funding to finance projects classified category A for environmental

impacts or category A or B for involuntary resettlement or indigenous peoples. Indosurya will apply 
ADB's Prohibited Investment Activities List, ensure that subloans using ADB funds abide by 
applicable national environmental laws and regulations, and comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement. Indosurya will also comply with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social 
Protection Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply with internationally recognized core 
labor standards.41 Indosurya will report regularly to ADB on its compliance with such laws and 
any measures taken. 
 
30.  Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998),  Indosurya  will  incorporate  measures  to  promote  gender  equality  and/or  women’s 
empowerment in its business activities.42 Key features of the GAP include (i) training sessions on 
business management, financial literacy, and gender sensitization; (ii) increasing the proportion 
of women employees and women in senior positions; (iii) strengthening policies on the prevention 
of sexual harassment; and (iv) establishing additional branches to specifically ease access to 
financial services by women clients. Indosurya will submit periodic reports on implementation of 
gender measures to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
31.  Indosurya was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
32.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),43 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of 
Indonesia has no objection to the proposed assistance to PT Indosurya Inti Finance. ADB will 
enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following 
approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$80,000,000, comprising (i) an A loan of up to $30,000,000 (or in its rupiah equivalent) from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources; and (ii) a B loan of up to $50,000,000 (in the event that the A loan or 
part of it is denominated in US dollars) to PT Indosurya Inti Finance for the Small and Medium-
Sized  Enterprise  Financing  Project  in  Indonesia,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The proposed loan to Indosurya will support the onlending and expansion of its small andmedium-sized enterprise (SME) loan portfolio. Funding from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide support for critically needed financial products and services to this underserved segment in Indonesia with targeted support for women SME clients and borrowers in less penetrated geographical markets, primarily outside Greater Jakarta.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated September 2019 is provided for the ADB project 53123-001 in Indonesia.
